name: NPR
text:
A woman was killed by a great white in Maine on Monday — the first fatal shark attack in the state's history. Officials urged swimmers and boaters to use caution near Bailey Island.
https://t.co/P3YzWlFrU6

name: NPR
text:
RT @NPRItsBeenAMin: How did best friends Aminatou Sow and Ann Friedman deal with a rough patch in their friendship? They went to friend therapy together. 

In this podcast episode they chat with @samsanders about that and their new book, "Big Friendship."

LISTEN NOW 🔊  https://t.co/0LhIwLukIA

name: NPR
text:
Jeff Bezos is set to make his first appearance before Congress on Wednesday as part of an anti-trust hearing with other tech CEOs.

Read his written testimony:
https://t.co/x5av4jL4ZW

name: NPR
text: The Trump administration is refusing to accept new applications while it undertakes a "comprehensive review" of DACA —  despite a ruling from the Supreme Court that  blocked President Trump’s effort to end the program last month. https://t.co/g1jTunjmt8

name: NPR
text:
Almost 300,000 nursing home residents are given antipsychotic drugs each week—despite most having no psychosis to justify it.

And under the Trump administration, nursing homes have rarely paid a price for even the most serious misuses, a new report finds.
https://t.co/HsypPYF5Ma

name: NPR
text:
With much of the Navajo Nation stuck at home due to the pandemic, one Navajo farmer is on a mission to help people return to their roots by teaching traditional farming techniques.
https://t.co/oLJvolOtYC

name: NPR
text: The Remington Arms Company, which has been making guns in the U.S. since 1816, filed for bankruptcy protection amid ongoing legal and financial challenges. https://t.co/QLV1tFd0LJ

name: NPR
text:
We've come to expect legal waivers for things like skiing or bungee-jumping.

But now colleges and businesses — from hair salons to dentists' offices — are using them to try to shield themselves from liability as they reopen during the pandemic.
https://t.co/ACAMOVGaoX

name: NPR
text: An Australian pub has banned two emus, siblings Kevin and Carol, after they learned to climb the pub steps and created havoc inside — stealing food from customers and loitering behind the bar. https://t.co/wWZhykx7PP

name: NPR
text: Republicans are signaling that the Census Bureau cannot take the extra time it needs to deliver the 2020 census amid the coronavirus pandemic — even if that risks severe inaccuracies in the once-a-decade count. https://t.co/82j0Kjv8Ua

name: NPR
text: The nation's second-largest teachers union says it will support its 1.7 million members going on strike if health precautions are not met amid calls for schools to reopen in the fall. https://t.co/ngz1mhlTVN

name: NPR
text:
It wasn't long ago that Nicolás Maduro's days as the Venezuelan president appeared to be numbered.

But he’s still hanging on — and the opposition is more divided than ever.
https://t.co/O72h1xJWrg

name: NPR
text:
A business owner in Minneapolis is trying to make amends after his daughter's past anti-Black, homophobic and anti-Semitic social media posts became public.

But after the damage has been done, what does a path forward look like? (@nprcodeswitch)
https://t.co/p35HxUMXOs

name: NPR
text:
Dr. Anthony Fauci is warning that the Midwest could be the next area to see a big surge in coronavirus cases. But there's still time to stop it, he says, if states follow the national guidelines on reopening safely.
https://t.co/6s9sHCnLcK

name: NPR
text:
With many school districts going online-only in the fall, a group of charter school leaders have launched a program aiming to deliver better online learning to any district that wants it.

Some worry the program is overpromising.
https://t.co/DfFyfTwivX

name: NPR
text:
Red Lobster staff in Ohio were unpacking a delivery of live crustaceans when they noticed something strange: a rare American blue lobster. Just 1 in 2 million are blue, researchers believe.

It was spared — and now lives at the Akron Zoo.
https://t.co/oWmJlYkMc0

name: NPR
text: The use of technologies that help some workers do their work remotely could have unanticipated, long-lasting effects on other workers with lower-paid jobs. https://t.co/GZ9GMCd9o6

name: NPR
text:
When she was 19, Natasha Trethewey's abusive stepfather shot and killed her mother — but his initial target was Trethewey. 

“I've lived with the survivor's guilt of that moment ever since," she says. https://t.co/hATmd5VWxc

name: NPR
text:
The power of moms as activists is being proven again by the Wall of Moms protesting in Portland.

Stereotypes about gender, as well as race, have long played a role in shaping that power — as well as who gets to wield it. https://t.co/IcM21QhtXm

name: NPR
text:
Considering getting into coffee as your next quarantine hobby? Here are some tips from @nprlifekit:

☕ start with good ingredients, including fresh coffee
☕ get a grinder
☕ develop your own recipe — try starting with 1 part coffee to 16 parts water
https://t.co/eBmDmLmwV2

name: NPR
text:
Wildebeests gallop across Africa, Monarch butterflies flit across the Americas ... but did you know that forests migrate, too?

Over millennia, forests creep inch by inch to more hospitable places. 
https://t.co/r528ALE6pQ

name: NPR
text:
Greg Reese used to have a Confederate  on his car. This year he replaced it with a bumper sticker bearing a new, inclusive Southern pride flag, and the words "Rednecks for Black Lives." 

He tells @hereandnow how he changed his views, and those of others. https://t.co/TBxlE3vHjI

name: NPR
text:
Taylor Swift’s surprise album, “Folklore,” is a big left turn in style and subject matter — and it’s already earned her some of the best reviews of her career.

3 critics dive into the new album 👇
https://t.co/QlqrCVR50F

name: NPR
text:
"If history is written by winners," author Maria Sherman says, "music history is written by rock critics, and they don't typically get along with boy bands."

Her new book gives critical consideration to the pop phenomenon. 🕺🕺🕺🕺🕺
https://t.co/06L6OVnw8g

name: NPR
text:
Kentucky singer-songwriter @SGGoodmanKY's debut album is filled with social commentary — from suicidal thoughts to the not-so-many differences between North and South.

She explains why everyone should be thinking about Kentucky politics.
https://t.co/UuisUR15Z5

name: NPR
text:
The staggering COVID-19 death toll doesn’t provoke the same type of emotional response a plane crash might.

"When you live in a war zone, after a while, everyday risk becomes just baseline," says psychologist Elke Weber. 
https://t.co/xXQK8rLCJd

name: NPR
text:
For her Tiny Desk, Thao Nguyen was joined by cellists (and neighbors) Elisabeth Reed and Andy Luchansky.

She performed a song that's an homage to her parents, who were refugees — and a celebration of being an openly queer musician.
https://t.co/HrXVK64Bxk

name: NPR
text:
Two governors — Michelle Lujan Grisham of New Mexico and Gretchen Whitmer of Michigan — are among those thought to be on Joe Biden's vice presidential shortlist.

The two have risen in prominence for their recent handling of crises on multiple fronts.
https://t.co/p0ZOCoaErL

name: NPR
text:
This Ohio county voted for every Democratic presidential candidate from 1988 to 2012 — then went to Trump in 2016.

Now, a new crop of local political leaders hope a younger generation of voters will help decide the 2020 election, and the county's future.
https://t.co/vyfRWbT4RE

name: NPR
text:
Scientists are now testing to see whether an infusion of antibodies from people who've recovered from COVID-19 could protect someone who's been exposed to the virus and is at high risk of infection.
https://t.co/mkAkExnX8b

name: NPR
text:
An NPR analysis of new cases and hospital capacity shows there's cause for concern in areas beyond well-known hotspots.

Hospital systems in Louisiana, Washington and Idaho have had to shuffle patients between hospitals to ensure people can get a bed.
https://t.co/S7rb3pK704
